intro: Lippia mcvaughii var. latifolia, commonly known as Mexican blueweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and thrives in full sun, making it well adapted to arid environments. Its foliage is often used in traditional medicine, and it is also valued as an ornamental plant for its resilience and visual appeal. The species is notable for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
